claims.text: The climate has changed remarkably little over the past 30 years.
The IPCC acknowledged in its 2007 report that long-term climate prediction is not possible.
The scenario that burning fossil fuels leads to catastrophe isn’t part of what either group asserts.
CO2 is a greenhouse gas without which life on earth is not possible.
Adding CO2 to the atmosphere should lead to some warming.
Atmospheric levels of CO2 have been increasing since the end of the Little Ice Age in the 19th century.
The global mean temperature has increased slightly and erratically by about 1.8 degrees Fahrenheit since the 1960s.
Scientists outside of climate physics have published papers blaming global warming for various issues.
I’ve published more than 200 scientific papers.
I taught at MIT for 30 years.
Group one consists of scientists associated with the IPCC.
Group two consists of scientists who don’t see climate change as a serious problem.
Group three consists mostly of politicians, environmentalists, and media.
The cry of 'global warming' has grown ever more shrill.
Group three is winning the argument because they have drowned out serious debate.

claim_reports.claim_text: The IPCC acknowledged in its 2007 report that long-term climate prediction is not possible.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence presents a mixed view on the claim. While one source indicates that the IPCC acknowledges limitations in long-term climate predictions, two other sources clarify that the IPCC does not state that such predictions are impossible, but rather emphasizes uncertainties in specific aspects. This suggests a nuanced understanding rather than a definitive acknowledgment of impossibility.

supports.title: [PDF] Long-term Climate Change: Projections, Commitments and ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the IPCC acknowledges limitations in its climate predictions, particularly regarding the influence of ice sheet dynamics on sea level rise, suggesting that long-term predictions are inherently uncertain.
supports.snippet: It is not even possible to make projections of the frequency of ... IPCC, 2007: Climate Change 2007: The Physical Science Basis. Contribution of.

mixed.title: Fact check: Climate models reliable, IPCC statement misrepresented
mixed.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that while the IPCC acknowledges limitations in predicting specific climate events, it does not claim that long-term climate predictions are impossible. Instead, it emphasizes uncertainties in specific aspects, such as the timing of weather events and the influence of ice sheet dynamics on sea level rise.
mixed.snippet: The IPCC statement accurately asserts that "climate states" such as weather events or the occurrence of an El Niño cannot be predicted very far in advance.

mixed.title: IPCC Predictions: Then Versus Now - Climate Central
mixed.evidence_summary: The article discusses the IPCC's acknowledgment of errors in its 2007 report, particularly regarding the melting of Himalayan glaciers, but it does not explicitly state that long-term climate prediction is impossible. Instead, it highlights the uncertainties in specific projections, such as sea level rise, due to factors like ice sheet dynamics.

claim_reports.claim_text: CO2 is a greenhouse gas without which life on earth is not possible.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that CO2 is a greenhouse gas essential for life on Earth. NASA confirms that greenhouse gases, including CO2, are vital for maintaining temperatures that support life, while the Senate Commerce Committee highlights CO2's role in the formation of fossil fuels, which have significantly impacted human life. Additionally, a climate.gov report emphasizes CO2's crucial role in heat absorption and radiation.

supports.title: [PDF] Carbon Dioxide Benefits the World: - Senate Commerce Committee
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses the role of CO2 in the formation of fossil fuels, which have significantly impacted human life, suggesting its importance in the context of life on Earth.
supports.snippet: Long-dead plants used CO2 from ancient atmospheres to produce most of the fossil fuels, coal, oil, and natural gas that have transformed the life of most humans ...

supports.title: Carbon Dioxide - Earth Indicator - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that greenhouse gases, including CO2, are essential for maintaining temperatures that support life on Earth, indicating that life would not be possible without them.
supports.snippet: Without any greenhouse gases, Earth would be too cold to support life. But the more greenhouse gases there are in the atmosphere, the warmer the planet becomes.

supports.title: Climate change: atmospheric carbon dioxide
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that carbon dioxide is a crucial greenhouse gas that plays a significant role in absorbing and radiating heat, which is essential for maintaining life on Earth.
supports.snippet: Carbon dioxide is Earth's most important long-lived greenhouse gas: a gas that absorbs and radiates heat. Unlike oxygen or nitrogen (which make up most of ...

unclear.evidence_summary: Carbon is essential to life on Earth. It is one of the four key elements that make up the human body—alongside hydrogen, oxygen, and nitrogen—and can be ...
unclear.snippet: Carbon is essential to life on Earth. It is one of the four key elements that make up the human body—alongside hydrogen, oxygen, and nitrogen—and can be ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Adding CO2 to the atmosphere should lead to some warming.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that adding CO2 to the atmosphere leads to warming, as multiple high-reliability sources confirm that increased CO2 levels, primarily from human activities, enhance the greenhouse effect and trap heat, resulting in global warming.

supports.title: Carbon Dioxide - Earth Indicator - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the increase in carbon dioxide (CO2) levels in the atmosphere, primarily due to human activities, is linked to warming the planet, as CO2 is a greenhouse gas that traps heat from sunlight.
supports.snippet: Carbon dioxide (CO2) is an important greenhouse gas. Greenhouse gases trap the heat from sunlight, warming the planet. Without any greenhouse gases, Earth.

supports.title: Climate change: atmospheric carbon dioxide
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that increasing carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere, primarily due to human activities, amplifies the natural greenhouse effect, leading to global warming.
supports.snippet: By adding more carbon dioxide to the atmosphere, people are amplifying the natural greenhouse effect, causing global temperature to rise.

supports.title: Carbon dioxide levels increase by record amount to new highs in 2024
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the increase in carbon dioxide (CO2) levels in the atmosphere is linked to warming the planet, as CO2 is a greenhouse gas that traps heat.
supports.snippet: “The heat trapped by CO2 and other greenhouse gases is turbo-charging our climate and leading to more extreme weather. Reducing emissions is ...

supports.title: How Exactly Does Carbon Dioxide Cause Global Warming?
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence explains that increasing CO2 in the atmosphere leads to a warming effect by altering the altitude of the layer from which infrared radiation can escape into space, thus creating an energy imbalance that results in warming.
supports.snippet: As carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases heat up the planet, more water evaporates into the atmosphere, which in turn raises the temperature ...

claim_reports.claim_text: The global mean temperature has increased slightly and erratically by about 1.8 degrees Fahrenheit since the 1960s.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that the global mean temperature has increased by about 1.8 degrees Fahrenheit since the 1960s, with multiple high-reliability sources indicating an increase of at least 1.1°C (1.9°F) since 1880 and significant warming since the 1970s. However, while the sources confirm the increase, they do not specifically address the erratic nature of the temperature changes.

supports.title: Climate change: global temperature
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the global mean temperature has increased by at least 1.1°C (1.9°F) since 1880, with significant warming occurring since the 1970s, which aligns with the claim of a slight increase since the 1960s.
supports.snippet: Earth's temperature has risen by an average of 0.11° Fahrenheit (0.06° Celsius) per decade since 1850, or about 2° F in total.

supports.title: Monthly Climate Reports | Global Climate Report | Annual 2018
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the global mean temperature has increased by at least 1.1°C (1.9°F) since 1880, with significant warming occurring since the 1970s, which aligns with the claim of a temperature increase since the 1960s, though it does not specify the erratic nature of the increase.
supports.snippet: The years 2015–2017 each had a global temperature departure from average that was more than 1.0°C (1.8°F) above the 1880–1900 average, which is a period that is ...

supports.title: World of Change: Global Temperatures - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the global mean temperature has increased by at least 1.1°C (1.9°F) since 1880, with significant warming occurring since the 1970s, which aligns with the claim of a temperature increase since the 1960s, though it does not specify the erratic nature of the increase.
supports.snippet: The average global temperature on Earth has increased by at least 1.1° Celsius (1.9° Fahrenheit) since 1880.

mixed.title: Climate at a Glance | Global Time Series
mixed.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that average global temperatures have increased by about 1 degree Celsius (1.7 degrees Fahrenheit) since 1880, with a steady increase noted since the 1960s. However, it does not specifically confirm the claim of a 1.8 degrees Fahrenheit increase since the 1960s, as it states a general increase without detailing the erratic nature mentioned in the claim.
mixed.snippet: Global Time Series ; November 1962, 0.11°C · 121 ; November 1961, 0.04°C · 109 ; November 1960, -0.11°C · 65 ; November 1959, -0.04°C · 86.

claim_reports.claim_text: Scientists outside of climate physics have published papers blaming global warming for various issues.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence presents a mixed view on the claim. While the AAAS article refutes the notion that scientists outside of climate physics are solely to blame for issues related to global warming, the NSF and NASA sources indicate that scientists from various fields recognize the impact of climate change. However, they do not specifically confirm that these scientists are publishing papers blaming global warming for various issues.

refutes.title: Richard Muller now convinced world is warming - AAAS
refutes.evidence_summary: The article discusses the overwhelming scientific consensus that human activities are the primary cause of global warming, which contradicts the notion that scientists outside of climate physics are solely to blame for various issues related to global warming.
refutes.snippet: A small group of scientific critics contend that global warming studies have been flawed in many ways, and it is premature to form a solid conclusion.

mixed.snippet: Scientists have resolved a key climate change mystery, showing that the annual global temperature today is the warmest in the past 10,000 years.

mixed.title: Evidence - NASA Science

mixed.snippet: There is unequivocal evidence that Earth is warming at an unprecedented rate. Human activity is the principal cause.

claim_reports.claim_text: The scenario that burning fossil fuels leads to catastrophe isn’t part of what either group asserts.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence presents a mixed view on the claim. While the Skeptical Science article refutes the idea that catastrophic scenarios are not part of the assertions made by Lindzen and Happer, the Outside Online article supports the claim by highlighting Lindzen's downplaying of catastrophic consequences. The David Suzuki Foundation source adds uncertainty due to its medium reliability and the controversial nature of Lindzen's claims.

refutes.title: Debunking Joe Rogan, Dick Lindzen, and Will Happer
refutes.evidence_summary: The article discusses the misconceptions presented by Lindzen and Happer regarding the effects of burning fossil fuels, emphasizing that the scientific consensus acknowledges significant warming effects from CO2 emissions, which contradicts the claim that such catastrophic scenarios are not part of their assertions.
refutes.snippet: Scientists were studying competing effects resulting from the burning of fossil fuels – cooling caused by sulfate aerosols that block sunlight ...

supports.title: An Inconvenient Expert
supports.evidence_summary: The article presents Richard Lindzen's perspective, which downplays the catastrophic consequences of burning fossil fuels and suggests that human-generated CO2 is not the primary cause of recent warming. Lindzen argues that much of the warming is due to natural fluctuations and does not lead to catastrophe, which aligns with the claim that such scenarios are not asserted by either group.

claim_reports.claim_text: Group three is winning the argument because they have drowned out serious debate.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence presents a mixed view on whether Group three is winning the argument by drowning out serious debate. On one hand, the RealClimate source suggests that debates may validate less serious opposition, implying that Group three could be dominating the discourse. Conversely, the Lindzen, Happer, and Cohen article supports the claim that formal debates perpetuate the idea of ongoing debate, aligning with the notion of Group three's dominance. However, other sources indicate that dissenting voices are being suppressed, adding complexity to the claim.

refutes.title: Global Warming debate - RealClimate
refutes.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses the potential drawbacks of participating in debates about global warming, suggesting that such events may validate less serious opposition and perpetuate the idea that the issue is still debatable. This implies that Group three, representing the denialist side, may be winning by dominating the discourse.

claim_reports.claim_text: Group two consists of scientists who don’t see climate change as a serious problem.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence presents a mixed view on the seriousness of climate change among scientists. While some, like Richard Lindzen, openly dismiss concerns about global warming, others acknowledge its reality but express skepticism about specific aspects, such as the accuracy of climate models. The presence of a significant percentage of scientists expressing doubt (estimated at 40%) further complicates the consensus.

transcript_data.text: I’m an atmospheric physicist. I’ve published more than 200 scientific papers. For 30 years I taught at MIT, during which time the climate has changed remarkably little. But the cry of “global warming” has grown ever more shrill. In fact, it seems that the less the climate changes, the louder the voices of the climate alarmists get. So, let’s clear the air and create a more accurate picture of where we really stand on the issue of global warming or, as it is now called -- climate change. There are basically three groups of people dealing with this issue. Groups one and two are scientists. Group three consists mostly, at its core, of politicians, environmentalists and media. Group one is associated with the scientific part of the United Nation’s International Panel on Climate Change or IPCC (Working Group 1). These are scientists who mostly believe that recent climate change is primarily due to man’s burning of fossil fuels -- oil, coal and natural gas. This releases C02, carbon dioxide, into the atmosphere and, they believe, this might eventually dangerously heat the planet. Group two is made up of scientists who don’t see this as an especially serious problem. This is the group I belong to. We’re usually referred to as skeptics. We note that there are many reasons why the climate changes -- the sun, clouds, oceans, the orbital variations of the earth, as well as a myriad of other inputs. None of these is fully understood, and there is no evidence that CO2 emissions are the dominant factor. But actually there is much agreement between both groups of scientists. The following are such points of agreement: 1) The climate is always changing. 2) CO2 is a greenhouse gas without which life on earth is not possible, but adding it to the atmosphere should lead to some warming. 3) Atmospheric levels of CO2 have been increasing since the end of the Little Ice Age in the 19th century. 4) Over this period (the past two centuries), the global mean temperature has increased slightly and erratically by about 1.8 degrees Fahrenheit or one degree Celsius; but only since the 1960’s have man’s greenhouse emissions been sufficient to play a role. 5) Given the complexity of climate, no confident prediction about future global mean temperature or its impact can be made. The IPCC, acknowledged in its own 2007 report that “The long-term prediction of future climate states is not possible.” Most importantly, the scenario that the burning of fossil fuels leads to catastrophe isn’t part of what either group asserts. So why are so many people worried, indeed, panic stricken about this issue. Here’s where Group Three comes in -- the politicians, environmentalists, and media. Global Warming Alarmism provides them, more than any other issue, with the things they most want: For politicians it’s money and power. For environmentalists it’s money for their organizations and confirmation of their near religious devotion to the idea that man is a destructive force acting upon nature. And for the media it’s ideology, money, and headlines -- doomsday scenarios sell. Meanwhile, over the last decade, scientists outside of climate physics have jumped on the bandwagon, publishing papers blaming global warming for everything from acne to the Syrian civil war. And, crony capitalists have eagerly grabbed for the subsidies that governments have so lavishly provided. Unfortunately, group three is winning the argument because they have drowned out the serious debate that should be going on. But while politicians, environmentalists and media types can waste a lot of money and scare a lot of people, they won’t be able to bury the truth. The climate will have the final word on that. I’m Richard Lindzen, emeritus professor of Atmospheric Sciences at MIT, for PragerUniversity.

segments.text:
I’m an atmospheric physicist. I’ve published
more than 200 scientific papers. For 30 years

I taught at MIT, during which time the climate
has changed remarkably little. But the cry

of “global warming” has grown ever more
shrill. In fact, it seems that the less the

climate changes, the louder the voices of
the climate alarmists get. So, let’s clear

the air and create a more accurate picture
of where we really stand on the issue of global

warming or, as it is now called -- climate
change.

There are basically three groups of people
dealing with this issue. Groups one and two

are scientists. Group three consists mostly,
at its core, of politicians, environmentalists

and media.
Group one is associated with the scientific

part of the United Nation’s International
Panel on Climate Change or IPCC (Working Group 1).

These are scientists who mostly believe
that recent climate change is primarily due

to man’s burning of fossil fuels -- oil,
coal and natural gas. This releases C02, carbon dioxide,

into the atmosphere and, they believe,
this might eventually dangerously heat the planet.
Group two is made up of scientists who don’t see this as an especially serious problem.
This is the group I belong to. We’re usually referred to as skeptics. We note that there are many reasons why the

climate changes -- the sun, clouds, oceans,
the orbital variations of the earth,

as well as a myriad of other inputs. None of these
is fully understood, and there is no evidence

that CO2 emissions are the dominant factor.
But actually there is much agreement between

both groups of scientists. The following are
such points of agreement:

1) The climate is always changing.
2) CO2 is a greenhouse gas without which life

on earth is not possible, but adding it to
the atmosphere should lead to some warming.

3) Atmospheric levels of CO2 have been increasing
since the end of the Little Ice Age in the 19th century.
4) Over this period (the past two centuries),

the global mean temperature has increased
slightly and erratically by about 1.8 degrees

Fahrenheit or one degree Celsius; but only
since the 1960’s have man’s greenhouse

emissions been sufficient to play a role.
5) Given the complexity of climate, no confident

prediction about future global mean temperature
or its impact can be made. The IPCC, acknowledged

in its own 2007 report that “The long-term
prediction of future climate states is not possible.”
Most importantly, the scenario that the burning of fossil fuels
leads to catastrophe isn’t part of what either group asserts.

So why are so many people worried, indeed, panic
stricken about this issue.
Here’s where Group Three comes in -- the politicians, environmentalists, and media.

Global Warming Alarmism provides them, more
than any other issue, with the things they

most want: For politicians it’s money and
power. For environmentalists it’s money

for their organizations and confirmation of
their near religious devotion to the idea

that man is a destructive force acting upon
nature. And for the media it’s ideology,

money, and headlines -- doomsday scenarios
sell.

Meanwhile, over the last decade, scientists
outside of climate physics have jumped on

the bandwagon, publishing papers blaming global
warming for everything from acne to the Syrian

civil war. And, crony capitalists have eagerly
grabbed for the subsidies that governments

have so lavishly provided.
Unfortunately, group three is winning the

argument because they have drowned out the
serious debate that should be going on.

But while politicians, environmentalists and
media types can waste a lot of money and scare

a lot of people, they won’t be able to bury
the truth. The climate will have the final word on that.
I’m Richard Lindzen, emeritus professor of Atmospheric Sciences at MIT, for PragerUniversity.
